Driving to my office, I routinely listen to sales and marketing talks. Guys like Jim Rohn, Jeffery Gitomer, online marketing guys like Rich Schefren and others.
;
;I’m always interested in new spins or old ways of marketing a business. As I recently closed a large real estate/business transaction I am even more focused today on how we can attract and keep customers.
;
;Consulting for small business is fun for me- mainly because I love it, and love talking with other like minded business owners. Now, there is another reason it is fun to be a consultant, there is less stress than being the actual business owners.
;
;Being an owner in 5 different business (brick and mortar) I know how stressful it is to start up and then find the right people to help grow it. One of my business, Video Influence Productions, I am marketing consultant for small business with their online social media and web video needs.
;
;If I screw up a marketing campaign (which is really a subjective test of the market place), I loose a client and some money. Now, I am not saying that I take this lightly, but it got me to thinking as the new business my partners and I started. We are in the process of hiring numerous consultants, some of which may include an offline marketing consultant.
;
;What shocked me was the attitude many of the consultants take. It is as if they figure money grows on trees and that there would be no consequences if things didn’t turn out.
;
;I will say this, the guys we hired, have been tremendous assets to our team so far. But, to find these diamonds in the rough (cliche, but true) took time and preparation on our part.
;
;Here are some lessons we learned, some costly, that I feel will help you in hiring a any consultant. I’ll gear it to hiring a marketing consultant, but think that most of the advice would be good principles to follow regardless of service provider or consultant.
;
;1. Always get at least 2 RFP’s (request for proposal).
;
;Can’t say how many times we met with the 1st provider and thought, well, lets go with these guys, they seem great. Only to find out that they were inferior to the competition.
;
;The other benefit to multiple interviews- you learn what questions to ask.
;
;Here is a great line my mentor taught me, at the end of any meeting
;
;“Thanks you for meeting with us. Was there any question we should have asked, that we did not?”
;
;2. Always get detailed quotes.
;
;Find out if they plan to charge you for putting together a quote. Some guys will expect you to pay them for putting together a quote- its not good or bad, just know ahead of time.
;
;3. Understand the terms of service.
;
;Too often the communicated request from the business owner to provider is lost in translation. Here is why it is even more critical to work with a seasoned professional.
;
;Many times there are questions that you may not ask (for various reasons) and can come back to haunt you.
;
;I always do this towards the end of the meeting.
;
;To recap- Here is the outcome and results I am after. Can you deliver these at the quoted price?
;
;How long will it take to deliver these results?
;
;What, if any circumstances do you foresee that may slow down or alter the results I am after?
;
;How do you handle ongoing support? Who takes calls after hours?
;
;So those are the 3 tips I thought would benefit your business. Hiring anyone is difficult these days. Finding the best takes time, but it is worth it.
;
;As an aside- not one of our consultant did we hire based on price or hourly rate. In fact, many of these guys are typically the best and thus charge 2-3x their competitors. But, here is the key: they deliver results and that is all that counts.
